biogHist.abstract: St Vincent's Foundling Home was run by the Sisters of Mercy from 1914 on the same site as the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage in Subiaco. It housed infants and children up to six years old who were both wards and 'privately placed'. Once they turned six, girls were sent to St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage and boys to Clontarf or (from 1929) Castledare. St Margaret's Hostel was built as an extension of St Vincent's in 1918, and from 1947 the Home received child migrants from Britain and Malta. In 1971, St Vincent's Foundling Home became part of the Catherine McAuley Centre.
biogHist.p: St Vincent's Foundling Home was a home for children under the age of six and it has been reported that many children who were admitted were unwell. The early reports submitted to the government record the number of children who died each year. The 1917 annual report of what was then the State Children Department (p.10) shows that 10 children died from causes such as meningitis, bronchitis or pneumonia, whooping cough, and 'entiritis'. Later government reports Signposts 2004, pp.470-471) also document the number of infants who died in the Home. As conditions for infants improved generally, these deaths were not as numerous as in previous years but in some years (as in 1926) up to four children died.

It was likely that the early years of St Vincent's Founding Home were characterised by poverty, within the institution, not only among those children admitted. A letter of appreciation of the The Daily News Orphans' Christmas Cheer Fund in 1915 gives an insight into life at St Vincent's in the early days, showing that donations enabled the children to occasionally have extras that were not part of their daily experience:

'As you desired, the money has been used for the purchase of toys for the little ones at the Foundling Home, and we are deeply grateful for your kindness in remembering them. Letter, 11 January 1916 published in The Daily News 2 December 1916, p.10'

In evidence to the Select Committee of the Legislative Council on the State Children Act Amendment Bill in October 1918, the Catholic Archbishop of Perth said that there were 76 infants in the Foundling Home, and described them in emotional terms as 'nearly all illegitimate', and often 'weaklings, everything possible having been done to destroy them before birth.' He said the children were generally sent to them by the Children's Court but that sometimes 'a mother comes along and tells a piteous tale, asking us to take her child, for which most often she promises to pay'. In those cases, the Archbishop said the church tried to pursue the father through the Children's Court to pay maintenance. He reported that these fathers usually paid 'a little at the start, and then they forget' but that some fathers were 'most faithful in the discharge of their obligation'.

In 1918, St Margaret's Hostel for 'unmarried mothers and their babies' was built as an extension of St Vincent's and in 1934 (Signposts p.471) a 'large and airy nursery and infirmary, together with an up-to-date kindergarten school' were added.
St Vincent's was a large Home. Government reports (Signposts pp.471-472) show that by 1921 there were 54 children in the Home and until 1948 there were around 50-60 children living there.
From 1947, St Vincent's admitted children who had been sent as unaccompanied child migrants from Britain and Malta.

A government report in 1952 (Signposts p.473) shows that St Vincent's was a starting point for children who could spend their childhoods in allied Children's Homes: When the children become of school age the girls are transferred to St Joseph's Orphanage and the boys to Castledare Junior Orphanage'. St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage, which is referred to in this quote, was alongside St Vincent's on the same plot of land. Castledare, was across the river in a southern suburb of Perth. Brothers and sisters who had been in St Vincent's were therefore separated by the time they reached school age.

Extensive renovations were reported in 1954 and in 1957 the annual report of the Child Welfare Department showed there were 152 children at St Vincent's at the end of the 1956-1957 year. Ninety two of these children were 'private admissions' (children who had been placed by family or others) and the private children far outweighed the number of children who were child migrants, wards or 'native wards' throughout the 1960s.
In 1971, St Vincent's Foundling Home became part of the Catherine McAuley Centre.

chronItem.event: Location - St Vincent's Foundling Home located on the same site as St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage in Subiaco

descriptiveNote.p: St Vincent's Foundling Home was part of the Catholic Immigration Scheme that sent children from Malta and Britain to Western Australia.

Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection (1894 - )
Children's Court of Western Australia (1907 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Some children were placed in St Vincent's by the Children's Court.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage (1901 - 1971)

descriptiveNote.p: St Joseph's Orphanage and St Vincent's Foundling Home were were close to each other at Subico. Younger children went to St Vincent's and older girls were housed at St Joseph's.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Castledare (1934 - 1983)

descriptiveNote.p: Boys often went to Castledare from St Vincent's Foundling Home when they were about six years old.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Catholic Child Welfare Council, United Kingdom (1929 - 2003)

descriptiveNote.p: The Catholic Child Welfare Council was involved in sending unaccompanied child migrants to St Vincent's Foundling Home from Britain.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association [CEMWA] (1947? - 1970)

descriptiveNote.p: The Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association [CEMWA] coordinated the placement of child migrants at St Vincent's Foundling Home.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Father Hudson's Society, United Kingdom (1902 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Father Hudson's Society was one of the Homes in Britain that sent child migrants to St Vincent's Foundling Home.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Ross Fact-Finding Mission [British child migration] (1956)

descriptiveNote.p: Ross Fact-Finding Mission [British child migration] was interested in the welfare of children at St Vincent's Foundling Home.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Native Ward (1964? - 1985?)

descriptiveNote.p: Children classified as Native Ward were noted in child welfare reports as living at St Vincent's Foundling Home.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Catherine McAuley Centre (1971 - 1991)

descriptiveNote.p: The Catherine McAuley Centre was established on the site of the former St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage in Subiaco.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: St Vincent's Foundling Home

archref.repository: Mercy Heritage Centre, Buildings 1.11 Subiaco/Wembley. Sisters of Mercy Perth congregation 1846 - 2013
archref.abstract: 'St Vincent's Foundling Home' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. As it is a colour photograph, it is likely that the image dates from the 1940s or later.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Subiaco Dormitory 2

archref.repository: Mercy Heritage Centre, Building/Ministry. B 1.00 Subiaco/Wembley . Sisters of Mercy Perth Congregation 1846 - 2013
archref.abstract: 'Subiaco Dormitory 2' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows a dormitory at the St Vincent's Foundling Home. An approximate date range of 1920s to 1960s has been given, based on the style of the dolls on the beds. It is possible that the picture was taken when the dormitory was decorated for a special event.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: St Vincent's children 2

archref.repository: Mercy Heritage Centre, Ministry. Subiaco/Wembley. 1.9 Sisters of Mercy Perth Congregation 1846 - 2013
archref.abstract: 'St Vincent's children 2' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows a group of young children and babies in front of the St Vincent's Foundling Home. Also present are older girls, who would have been from the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage. These older girls helped staff and sisters care for the children in St Vincent's. An approximate date range of 1914 to 1950s has been given, based on the children's clothing.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Foundling Home 2

archref.repository: Mercy Heritage Centre, Ministry Subiaco/Wembley 2.7 Sisters of Mercy Perth Congregation 1846 - 2013
archref.abstract: 'Foundling Home 2' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows a group of young children and babies in front of the St Vincent's Foundling Home. An approximate date range of 1914 to 1950s has been given, based on the children's clothing.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: CEMWA Response to Moss Questionnaire

archref.abstract: 'CEMWA Response to Moss Questionnaire' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. There is an undated letter from the Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association Inc, responding to questions about Bindoon, Clontarf, Castledare,Nazareth House, St Joseph's Orphanage (including St Vincent's Foundling Home), and Tardun. There is also a letter, dated 14 August 1951, from the Under Secretary for Lands and Immigration passing on further information about staffing at those institutions.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia

archref.unittitle: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia
archref.abstract: 'Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It is the questionnaire that was circulated to government, the organisations that received and placed child migrants, and the children's Homes where the children lived. This questionnaire was received by the Commonwealth Government on 10 May 1951.

archref.abstract: This is a digital copy of the report which is published in the Votes and Proceedings of the Parliament of Western Australia.

archref.abstract: This is a digital copy of a photograph of a dormitory bedroom at St Vincent's Foundling Home in 1948. It is from the National Archives of Australia's collection of online images that were made available by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs.

archref.abstract: This is a digital copy of a photograph of the dining room at St Vincent's Foundling Home in 1948. It is from the National Archives of Australia's collection of online images that were made available by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: St Vincent's Foundling Home, Subiaco [picture]

archref.abstract: This is a digital copy of a photograph of the front entrance of St Vincent's Foundling Home in 1953. It is from the State Library of Western Australia's collection of online images that were made available by the Historical Records Rescue Consortium Project supported by Lotterywest.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Happy and Carefree Natures Caught By the Cameraman In These Studies of Young Western Australians

archref.unittitle: Happy and Carefree Natures Caught By the Cameraman In These Studies of Young Western Australians
archref.abstract: This is a picture from the Sunday Times newspaper, which is published on the National Library of Australia's website, 'Trove'. It shows a small boy who is being 'offered' for adoption. He is included with three other children in an article seeking adoptive parents for children who were wards of the state.
